days.subtitle: Xcode Essentials
days.description: In this video, I'll tell you what you need to learn and give you a tour of Xcode.

video.title: How to Make an App for Beginners - Lesson 1

questions.question: What software do we use to develop iOS apps?

answers.feedback: No, Xcode is Apple's Integrated Development Environment (IDE).
Yes, Xcode is Apple's Integrated Development Environment (IDE).
No, Xcode is Apple's Integrated Development Environment (IDE).

questions.question: What programming language are we learning in this course?

answers.feedback: Yes, Swift is the preferred programming language for Xcode projects.
No, Swift is the preferred programming language for Xcode projects.
No, Swift is the preferred programming language for Xcode projects.

questions.question: What file do we use to configure the screen that the user sees?

answers.feedback: Yes, Main.storyboard is the file in which the user interface is configured.
No, Main.storyboard is the file in which the user interface is configured.
No, Main.storyboard is the file in which the user interface is configured.

days.subtitle: All About Auto Layout
days.description: Jumping right in, you'll learn how to build layouts.

questions.question: What are Auto Layout constraints, and why do we use them when positioning elements on screen?

answers.text: Auto Layout constraints are rules that tell Xcode the location and size of our elements relative to other elements. We use constraints to ensure that our user interface looks good on multiple devices.
answers.feedback: Yes, Auto Layout constraints are rules that tell Xcode the location and size of our elements relative to other elements. We use constraints to ensure that our user interface looks good on multiple devices.

answers.text: Auto Layout constraints are systems that tell us whether our user interface is pretty or not. We use constraints to prevent us from having to decide if our user interface looks good on our own.
answers.feedback: No, Auto Layout constraints are rules that tell Xcode the location and size of our elements relative to other elements. We use constraints to ensure that our user interface looks good on multiple devices.

answers.text: Auto Layout constraints are an old way of creating user interfaces that were replaced by frames. We used constraints to tell Xcode the exact X and Y coordinates, as well as the exact width and height, for our elements.
answers.feedback: No, Auto Layout constraints are rules that tell Xcode the location and size of our elements relative to other elements. We use constraints to ensure that our user interface looks good on multiple devices.

questions.question: What will happen if we add two conflicting constraints to an element?

answers.text: Xcode will display a message when we run our app, asking us which constraints we want to keep and which we want to break.
answers.feedback: No, Xcode will choose one of the constraints to break, leading to unintended behaviour when we run our app.

answers.text: Xcode will choose one of the constraints to break, leading to unintended behaviour when we run our app.
answers.feedback: Yes, Xcode will choose one of the constraints to break, leading to unintended behaviour when we run our app.

answers.text: Nothing will happen. Xcode is smart enough to know how we want our user interface to look like even if we add conflicting constraints.
answers.feedback: No, Xcode will choose one of the constraints to break, leading to unintended behaviour when we run our app.

questions.question: What is the Safe Area?

answers.text: The Safe Area makes sure that the elements you add to your view will not be obscured by the notch or the home indicator.
answers.feedback: Yes, the Safe Area makes sure that the elements you add to your view will not be obscured by the notch or the home indicator.

answers.text: The Safe Area is a place in Xcode to write code that will never have any errors.
answers.feedback: No, the Safe Area makes sure that the elements you add to your view will not be obscured by the notch or the home indicator.

answers.text: The Safe Area is a type of element that tells the user of your app where it is safe to click.
answers.feedback: No, the Safe Area makes sure that the elements you add to your view will not be obscured by the notch or the home indicator.

days.subtitle: How To Use Stack Views
days.description: Learn how to use Stack View elements to build layouts much more easily.

questions.question: What is a StackView?

answers.text: A term that describes when multiple elements are stacked on top of one another.
answers.feedback: No, it is a user interface element that arranges other user interface elements inside of it in a stacked layout.

answers.text: A user interface element that arranges other user interface elements inside of it in a stacked layout.
answers.feedback: Yes, it is a user interface element that arranges other user interface elements inside of it in a stacked layout.
No, it is a user interface element that arranges other user interface elements inside of it in a stacked layout.

questions.question: What are the two types of StackViews in Xcode?

answers.text: A Horizontal StackView and and a Vertical StackView.
answers.feedback: Yes, the two types of StackViews used in Xcode are a Horizontal StackView and and a Vertical StackView.

answers.text: A left/right StackView and an up/down StackView.
answers.feedback: No, the two types of StackViews used in Xcode are a Horizontal StackView and and a Vertical StackView.

answers.text: There are more than two types of StackViews in Xcode.
answers.feedback: No, the two types of StackViews used in Xcode are a Horizontal StackView and and a Vertical StackView.

questions.question: What is the preferred way to add elements to a StackView?

answers.text: Drag elements into our StackView using our view.
answers.feedback: No, we drag elements into our StackView using the Document Outline because it is easier to place them correctly.

answers.text: Use our voice to tell Xcode to add elements.
answers.feedback: No, we drag elements into our StackView using the Document Outline because it is easier to place them correctly.

answers.text: Drag elements into our StackView using the Document Outline.
answers.feedback: Yes, we drag elements into our StackView using the Document Outline because it is easier to place them correctly.

days.subtitle: Assembling the War User Interface
days.description: Put your skills to the test by building the UI for our War Card Game.

questions.question: Where do we add images to our project in Xcode?

answers.feedback: Yes, we add images to our project by placing them in Assets.xcassets which is the Assets catalogue.
No, we add images to our project by placing them in Assets.xcassets which is the Assets catalogue.
No, we add images to our project by placing them in Assets.xcassets which is the Assets catalogue.

questions.question: What are size classes?

answers.text: Size classes are categories of screen sizes that you can target your Auto Layout constraints against.
answers.feedback: Yes, size classes are categories of screen sizes that you can target your Auto Layout constraints against.

answers.text: Size class is another name for Auto Layout constraints that deal with the height and width of user interface elements.
answers.feedback: No, size classes are categories of screen sizes that you can target your Auto Layout constraints against.
No, size classes are categories of screen sizes that you can target your Auto Layout constraints against.

questions.question: We add three of the same image to Xcode because

answers.text: Xcode will use the correct sized image depending on the resolution of the user's screen.
answers.feedback: Yes, Xcode will use the correct sized image depending on the resolution of the user's screen which is why there are 3 sizes added to the assets catalogue.

answers.text: the user might accidentally delete one of the images.
answers.feedback: No, Xcode will use the correct sized image depending on the resolution of the user's screen which is why there are 3 sizes added to the assets catalogue.

answers.text: Xcode requires us to have a backup of all of our images.
answers.feedback: No, Xcode will use the correct sized image depending on the resolution of the user's screen which is why there are 3 sizes added to the assets catalogue.

days.subtitle: Learn Swift Basics (Part 1)
days.description: Get hands on with the Swift programming language.

questions.question: How do we add a comment to our Swift code?

answers.feedback: Yes, we add comments to our code by prefixing the line with two forward slashes (//)
No, we add comments to our code by prefixing the line with two forward slashes (//)
No, we add comments to our code by prefixing the line with two forward slashes (//)

questions.question: What’s the difference between a variable and a constant?

answers.text: We can't reassign data to a variable after the first assignment of data to it.
answers.feedback: No, we can reassign data to a variable but we can't reassign data to a constant after the first assignment of data to it. A constant is immutable.

answers.text: We can't reassign data to a constant after the first assignment of data to it.
answers.feedback: Yes, we can't reassign data to a constant after the first assignment of data to it whereas we can reassign data to a varaiable. A constant is immutable.

answers.text: A constant must initially be assigned data when it's declared.
answers.feedback: No, we can't reassign data to a constant after the first assignment of data to it whereas we can reassign data to a varaiable. A constant is immutable.

questions.question: What happens when you don’t specify a data type for your variable when you declare it?

answers.text: The variable will be able to store any data type.
answers.feedback: No, if you don't specify the type of value you need, Swift uses type inference to work out the appropriate type.

answers.text: The variable will infer the data type from the first piece of data you assign to it.
answers.feedback: Yes, if you don't specify the type of value you need, Swift uses type inference to work out the appropriate type.
No, if you don't specify the type of value you need, Swift uses type inference to work out the appropriate type.

days.subtitle: Learn Swift Basics (Part 2)
days.description: Build upon the skills from the previous lesson and learn more about Swift programming.

questions.question: In Swift, what is a function?

answers.text: A function is a mathematical operation performed on numbers.
answers.feedback: No, a function is a block of code with a name that can be executed when called by its name.

answers.text: A function is a block of code with a name that can be executed when called by its name.
answers.feedback: Yes, a function is a block of code with a name that can be executed when called by its name.

answers.text: A function is for storing values in a class.
answers.feedback: No, a function is a block of code with a name that can be executed when called by its name.

questions.question: What is the difference between declaring a function and calling a function?

answers.text: Declaring a function is writing the code that you want to be executed when the function is called. Calling a function is running the code that is inside of the function.
answers.feedback: Yes, declaring a function is writing the code that you want to be executed when the function is called. Calling a function is running the code that is inside of the function.
No, there is a difference. Declaring a function is writing the code that you want to be executed when the function is called. Calling a function is running the code that is inside of the function.

answers.text: Declaring a function is the same as declaring a variable. Calling a function is the same as declaring a constant.
answers.feedback: No, declaring a function is writing the code that you want to be executed when the function is called. Calling a function is running the code that is inside of the function.

questions.question: Variables declared in a function won’t exist outside of the function. This is called variable scope. True or false?

answers.feedback:
Yes, variables declared in a function won’t exist outside of the function.  This is known as variable scope.

A variable defined at the class level is available to all functions within that class.

No, variables declared in a function do not exist outside of the function due to variable scope.

A variable defined at the class level is available to all functions within that class.

days.subtitle: Learn Swift Basics (Part 3)
days.description: Finally, we put it all together and I'll tell you how Swift code plays a part in your app.

questions.question: What is a class?

answers.text: A class is a way to organize your code into a template that can be used to create objects from.
answers.feedback: Yes, a class is a way to organize your code into a template that can be used to create objects from.

answers.text: A class is a category of code that is used for creating objects.
answers.feedback: No, a class is a way to organize your code into a template that can be used to create objects from.

answers.text: A class is a way for you to execute a block of code by calling its name.
answers.feedback: No, a class is a way to organize your code into a template that can be used to create objects from.

questions.question: What is a property?

answers.text: A property is another name for a function inside of a class.
answers.feedback: No, a property is another name for a variable inside of a class.

answers.text: A property is another name for a variable inside of a class.
answers.feedback: Yes, a property is another name for a variable inside of a class.

answers.text: A property stores a value in a function.
answers.feedback: No, a property is another name for a variable inside of a class.

questions.question: What is the difference between a function and a method?

answers.text: A method is what a function is called when it’s in a class.
answers.feedback: Yes, both of them are reusable chunks of code, but methods belong to classes, structs, and enums, whereas functions do not.

answers.text: A method is for handling button taps whereas functions are for executing other blocks of code.
answers.feedback: No, both of them are reusable chunks of code, but methods belong to classes, structs, and enums, whereas functions do not.

answers.text: A method is what a function is called if it has a return value.
answers.feedback: No, both of them are reusable chunks of code, but methods belong to classes, structs, and enums, whereas functions do not.

days.subtitle: Connecting Elements With Swift Code
days.description: You'll learn how to connect the elements in your layout to the Swift code that you write.

video.title: IBOutlet Properties and IBAction Methods - Lesson 8

questions.question: What is the difference between an IBOutlet property and an IBAction method? Select the most accurate statement below.

answers.text: An IBOutlet property connects to a user interface element in the storyboard and gives you a reference to it.
answers.feedback: No, an IBOutlet property connects to a user interface element in the storyboard and gives you a reference to it AND an IBAction method connects to an event raised by a user interface element in the storyboard and executes when the event is triggered.

answers.text: An IBAction method connects to an event raised by a user interface element in the storyboard and executes when the event is triggered.
answers.feedback: No, IBAction method connects to an event raised by a user interface element in the storyboard and executes when the event is triggered AND an IBOutlet property connects to a user interface element in the storyboard and gives you a reference to it.

Yes, both are correct. An IBOutlet property connects to a user interface element in the storyboard and gives you a reference to it AND an IBAction method connects to an event raised by a user interface element in the storyboard and executes when the event is triggered.

questions.question: What is the preferred way to fix a typo in an IBOutlet property to avoid our app crashing?

answers.text: Fix the typo directly in the ViewController and rerun the app.
answers.feedback:
No, you must break the connection, delete the property in the ViewController, and redo the connection.

Alternatively, you can right click the property name and select Refactor > Rename to rename a connection and that will correct the entry in both the swift file and the associated storyboard.

answers.text: Break the connection, delete the property in the ViewController, and redo the connection.
answers.feedback:
Yes, you must break the connection, delete the property in the ViewController, and redo the connection.

Alternatively, you can right click the property name and select Refactor > Rename to rename a connection and that will correct the entry in both the swift file and the associated storyboard.

answers.text: Nicely ask Xcode to correct the typo.
answers.feedback:
No, you must break the connection, delete the property in the ViewController, and redo the connection.

Alternatively, you can right click the property name and select Refactor > Rename to rename a connection and that will correct the entry in both the swift file and the associated storyboard.

questions.question: Where should you look for the reason for an app crash in Xcode?

answers.text: At the top of the debug console.
answers.feedback:
Yes, you should look at the top of the debug console.

In the event of a crash, the debug console will contain a lot of information but the important details to help you identfy the problem are generally at the top.

answers.text: At the bottom of the debug console.
answers.feedback:
No, you should look at the top of the debug console.

In the event of a crash, the debug console will contain a lot of information but the important details to help you identfy the problem are generally at the top.

No, you should look at the top of the debug console.

In the event of a crash, the debug console will contain a lot of information but the important details to help you identfy the problem are generally at the top.

days.subtitle: Handling User Interaction
days.description: Learn how to capture and handle taps from the user.

questions.question: We created IBOutlets for our leftImageView and our rightImageView because

answers.text: we need to be able to access the image views both in the storyboard and in our code.
answers.feedback: Yes, we need to be able to change both imageViews to show the newly selected cards each time the user taps the deal button.

answers.text: that's the only way to access them.
answers.feedback: No, we need to be able to change both imageViews to show the newly selected cards each time the user taps the deal button.

answers.text: Xcode requires that we create IBOutlets for our elements.
answers.feedback: No, we need to be able to change both imageViews to show the newly selected cards each time the user taps the deal button.

questions.question: How do we generate a random number in Swift?

answers.feedback: No, the code is: Int.random(in: lowerBound...upperBound)
Yes, the code is: Int.random(in: lowerBound...upperBound)
No, the code is: Int.random(in: lowerBound...upperBound)

questions.question: What property do we use to change the image of a UIImageView?

answers.feedback:
Yes, we change the image by using the assignment:
imageView.image = newUIImage

No, we change the image by using the assignment:
imageView.image = newUIImage

No, we change the image by using the assignment:
imageView.image = newUIImage

days.subtitle: Writing The Logic
days.description: Learn how to write code that THINKS!

video.title: Coding Logic with IF Statements - Lesson 10

questions.question: What happens if two conditions in an if statement are true?

answers.text: Xcode will execute the relevant code for both conditions.
answers.feedback: No, Xcode will execute the code relevant to the first true condition and ignore the other.

answers.text: Xcode will completely ignore your if statement, and no code will be executed.
answers.feedback: No, Xcode will execute the code relevant to the first true condition and ignore the other.

answers.text: Xcode will execute the code relevant to the first true condition.
answers.feedback: Yes, Xcode will execute the code relevant to the first true condition and ignore the other.

questions.question: What is the difference between = and ==?

answers.text: == is for assignment, while = checks for equality.
answers.feedback: No, == checks for equality, while = is for assignment.

answers.text: == checks for equality, while = is for assignment.
answers.feedback: Yes, == checks for equality, while = is for assignment.

answers.text: There is no difference between = and ==.
answers.feedback: No, == checks for equality, while = is for assignment.

questions.question: What symbol do we use to check if two values are not equal?

answers.feedback: Yes, != is used to check if two values are not equal.  The '!' means NOT
No, != is used to check if two values are not equal.  The '!' means NOT
No, != is used to check if two values are not equal.  The ! means NOT

days.subtitle: What You'll Learn Next
days.description: Continue building your Swift skills, learn some critical concepts, build more complex apps and express more complex logic with your Swift code.

page.headerText:
DAYS 11 – 17:
Step Up Your Swift Skills
page.bodyText:
It’s time to dive a little deeper into the Swift programming language!

Apple has a lot of documentation available to help and if you’re going to be building apps, you’d better know how to read it.

By Day 17, you’ll know how to read Apple documentation and you’ll know how to express deeper logic using Swift code.

days.subtitle: Where to Get Help on UIKit Classes
days.description: Learn 4 different techniques to find documentation and help on UIKit classes and methods.

days.subtitle: Subclassing
days.description: Learn how classes can "build off" of one another. It's called class inheritance and subclassing. It will save you a ton of time by not rewriting code!

questions.question: In Swift, subclassing lets us

answers.text: create a new class based on an existing class.
answers.feedback: Yes, subclassing lets us create a new class based on an existing class.

answers.text: duplicate code throughout our entire Xcode project.
answers.feedback: No, subclassing lets us create a new class based on an existing class.

answers.text: ask Xcode to write all of our classes for us.
answers.feedback: No, subclassing lets us create a new class based on an existing class.

questions.question: In Swift, inheritance allows the subclass to

answers.text: inherit the properties of the superclass.
answers.feedback: No, not only does inheritance allow the subclass to inherit the properties of the superclass, it also inherits the methods of the superclass.

answers.text: inherit the methods of the superclass.
answers.feedback: No, not only does inheritance allow the subclass to inherit the methods of the superclass, it also inherits the properties of the superclass.
Yes, inheritance allows the subclass to inherit the properties and methods of the superclass.

questions.question: What keyword do we use to call the parent's version of an overridden method?

answers.feedback: No, the keyword we use to call the parent's version of an overridden method is 'super'.
No, the keyword we use to call the parent's version of an overridden method is 'super'.
Yes, the keyword we use to call the parent's version of an overridden method is 'super'.

days.subtitle: Arrays
days.description: Learn how to work with collections of data by using an Array!

questions.question: If we wanted to access the first element in an array, what index would we use?

answers.feedback: Yes, if we wanted to access the first element in an array, we would use index 0.
No, if we wanted to access the first element in an array, we would use index 0.  Index 1 is the second element.
No, if we wanted to access the first element in an array, we would use index 0.  Index 2 is the third element.

questions.question: Choose the best answer to complete the following sentence: An array is one of the three ________ in Swift.

answers.feedback: Yes, an array is one of the three collection types in Swift.
No, an array is one of the three collection types in Swift.
No, an array is one of the three collection types in Swift.

questions.question: An array is ideal for data where order matters. True or false?

answers.feedback: Yes, an array is ideal for data where order matters.
No, an array is ideal for data where order matters.

days.subtitle: Optionals
days.description: Think of optionals simply as variables that might contain nil. The only hard part is remembering all of the syntax around optionals.

questions.question: What is the keyword that means “nothing” or “empty” in Swift?

answers.feedback: Yes, the keyword that means “nothing” or “empty” in Swift is nil.
No, the keyword that means “nothing” or “empty” in Swift is nil.
No, the keyword that means “nothing” or “empty” in Swift is nil.

questions.question: Any variable/constant can be made an optional by adding “?” beside the data type when you declare it. True or false?

answers.feedback: Yes, any variable/constant can be made an optional by adding “?” beside the data type when you declare it.
No, any variable/constant can be made an optional by adding “?” beside the data type when you declare it.

questions.question: You must unwrap an implicitly unwrapped optional variable/constant by using “!” before you can access it. True or false?

answers.feedback: No, you do not have to unwrap an implicitly unwrapped optional variable/constant by using “!” before you can access it.
Yes, you do not have to unwrap an implicitly unwrapped optional variable/constant by using “!” before you can access it.

days.subtitle: Dictionaries
days.description: You've learned about Arrays. Dictionaries are another often used and highly useful tool to keep track of collections of data!

questions.question: A dictionary is ideal for data where order matters. True or false?

answers.feedback: No, a dictionary is ideal for data where order does not matter.  It uses 'key: value' pairs where the key must be unique but the data can be randomly ordered.
Yes, a dictionary is ideal for data where order does not matter.  It uses 'key: value' pairs where the key must be unique but the data can be randomly ordered.

questions.question: What happens if we try to access a value in a dictionary using a key that does not exist in our dictionary?

answers.text: A dictionary always gives us back an optional value, so our app will crash if we try to use it.
answers.feedback: No, a dictionary always gives us back an optional value, so we can check to see if it's nil before unwrapping and using it.

answers.text: A dictionary always forces us to use keys that exist, so our program will not run if the key doesn't exist.
answers.feedback: No, a dictionary always gives us back an optional value, so we can check to see if it's nil before unwrapping and using it.

answers.text: A dictionary always gives us back an optional value, so we can check to see if it's nil before unwrapping and using it.
answers.feedback: Yes, a dictionary always gives us back an optional value, so we can check to see if it's nil before unwrapping and using it.

questions.question: We can use optional binding to access values in a dictionary. True or false?

answers.feedback: Yes, we can use optional binding to access values in a dictionary.
No, we can use optional binding to access values in a dictionary.

days.subtitle: Loops
days.description: Loops come in handy to let you go through each item in the collection and execute some code for each!

questions.question: Which loop will repeat for a finite number of times?

answers.feedback: No, a Repeat-While loop will repeat at least once and any number of times under control of the conditional clause.
No, a While loop will repeat between 0 and any number of times under control of the conditional clause.
Yes, a For-In Loop will repeat for a finite number of times.

questions.question: A loop is used to increase the amount of duplicated code in our projects. True or false?

answers.feedback:
No, a loop is used to DECREASE the amount of duplicated code in our projects.

In fact it is used to perform repetitive operations which result in less code.

Yes, a loop is used to DECREASE the amount of duplicated code in our projects.

In fact it is used to perform repetitive operations which result in less code.

questions.question: Which collection types are loops most commonly used with?

answers.feedback: Yes, loops are most commonly used to iterate over Arrays & Dictionaries.
No, loops are most commonly used to iterate over Arrays & Dictionaries.
No, loops are most commonly used to iterate over Arrays & Dictionaries.

days.subtitle: Previewing What You'll Build
days.description: In this lesson, I'll show you the app you'll build as well as all of the new skills you'll learn!

page.bodyText:
With the skills you’ve gained up to this point, you’re ready to start your second app!

By Day 28, you’ll know how to do animations, play sounds and follow some best practices for iOS development.

You’ll also learn how to troubleshoot and debug your Swift code.

days.subtitle: Model View Controller
days.description: Learn about a KEY design pattern that will help you write reusable code that is easily maintained.

video.title: The Card Game: The MVC Design Pattern - Lesson 19

questions.question: What do the letters MVC stand for?

answers.feedback: No, the letters MVC stand for 'Model View Controller'.
Yes, the letters MVC stand for 'Model View Controller'.
No, the letters MVC stand for 'Model View Controller'.

questions.question: In the MVC design pattern, which of these is NOT the responsibility of the View?

answers.text: Display the user interface and data.
answers.feedback: No, the View IS responsible for displaying the user interface and data.
No, the View IS responsible for detecting events from the user.

answers.text: Manage the data in our app.
answers.feedback:
Yes, the View is not responsible for managing the data in our Apps.

Managing data is the responsibility of the Model.

questions.question: In the MVC design pattern, the View should talk directly to the Model. True or false?

answers.feedback:
No, in the MVC design pattern, the View should NOT talk directly to the Model.

The View communicates to the Model through the ViewController.

Yes, in the MVC design pattern, the View should NOT talk directly to the Model.

The View communicates to the Model through the ViewController.

days.subtitle: Project Setup
days.description: Here we create the Xcode project, including setting the orientation for the app and setting up some of the user interface elements!

video.title: The Card Game: Project Setup - Lesson 20

days.subtitle: Custom Classes
days.description: In this lesson, you'll be setting up the custom classes that we talked about earlier.

video.title: The Card Game: Custom Classes - Lesson 21

questions.question: What are we going to do with our custom Card class?

answers.text: Create Card objects from the Card class.
answers.feedback: Yes, we are going to create Card objects from the Card class.

answers.text: Store the Card class in an array.
answers.feedback: No, we are going to create Card objects from the Card class.

answers.text: Use the Card class to create Strings.
answers.feedback: No, we are going to create Card objects from the Card class.

questions.question: Thinking back to the MVC design pattern, is the Card class a Model, View, or Controller?

answers.feedback: Yes, the Card class is a Model where the data is stored or generated.
No, the Card class is a Model where the data is stored or generated.
No, the Card class is a Model where the data is stored or generated.

questions.question: Thinking back to the MVC design pattern, is the CardCollectionViewCell class a Model, View, or Controller?

answers.feedback: No, the CardCollectionViewCell class is a View.
Yes, the CardCollectionViewCell class is a View.
No, the CardCollectionViewCell class is a View.

days.subtitle: Protocols & Delegates
days.description: The protocol and delegate pattern is used by many user interface elements in UIKit to communicate with the view controller.

video.title: The Card Game: Protocols and Delegates - Lesson 22

questions.question: What is a protocol?

answers.text: A predefined set of methods and parameters that will be used for two parties to communicate.
answers.feedback: No, not only is a protocol is both a predefined set of methods and parameters that will be used for two parties to communicate but it is also a way for one class to communicate with another class.

answers.text: A way for one class to communicate with another class.
answers.feedback: No, not only is a protocol a way for one class to communicate with another class but it is also a predefined set of methods and parameters that will be used for two parties to communicate.
Yes, a protocol is both a predefined set of methods and parameters that will be used for two parties to communicate.  It is also a way for one class to communicate with another class.

questions.question: What is a delegate?

answers.text: An object that conforms to a protocol by implementing the methods as described by the protocol.
answers.feedback: Yes, a 'delegate' is an object that conforms to a protocol by implementing the methods as described by the protocol.

answers.text: An object that has a protocol.
answers.feedback: No, a 'delegate' is an object that conforms to a protocol by implementing the methods as described by the protocol.
No, a 'delegate' is an object that conforms to a protocol by implementing the methods as described by the protocol.

questions.question: A class has to know and care what class conforms to its delegate. True or false?

answers.feedback: No, a class does NOT have to know NOR care what class conforms to its delegate. All the class with the delegate knows about is that the functions in the protocol are implemented.
Yes, a class does NOT have to know NOR care what class conforms to its delegate.  All the class with the delegate knows about is that the functions in the protocol are implemented.

questions.question: What is a naming convention?

answers.text: The only way to name your variables, methods, classes etc.
answers.feedback: No, a naming convention is a standard way to name variables, methods, classes etc, that is agreed upon by you and your team.

answers.text: Apple’s way to name variables, methods, classes etc.
answers.feedback: No, a naming convention is a standard way to name variables, methods, classes etc, that is agreed upon by you and your team.

answers.text: A standard way to name variables, methods, classes etc that is agreed upon by you and your team.
answers.feedback: Yes, a naming convention is a standard way to name variables, methods, classes etc, that is agreed upon by you and your team.

questions.question: According to best practice, what should each word in a class name start with?

answers.feedback: Yes, according to best practice, each word in a class name should start with a capital letter.
No, according to best practice, each word in a class name should start with a capital letter.
No, according to best practice, each word in a class name should start with a capital letter.

questions.question: What is the preferred structure for naming methods and functions?

answers.feedback:
Yes, the preferred structure for naming methods and functions is verbNoun.

For example getCards() - 'get' being the verb and 'Cards' being the noun.

No, the preferred structure for naming methods and functions is verbNoun.

For example getCards() - 'get' being the verb and 'Cards' being the noun.

No, the preferred structure for naming methods and functions is verbNoun.

For example getCards() - 'get' being the verb and 'Cards' being the noun.

questions.question: What is logging?

answers.text: A debugging technique where you output information to the console area.
answers.feedback: Yes, logging is a debugging technique where you output information to the console area.

answers.text: A debugging technique where you pause the execution of code.
answers.feedback: No, logging is a debugging technique where you output information to the console area.

answers.text: A debugging technique where you walk through the code line by line.
answers.feedback: No, logging is a debugging technique where you output information to the console area.

questions.question: How do you log something?

answers.feedback: Yes, you log something by making use of the print function.
No, you log something by making use of the print function.
No, you log something by making use of the print function.

questions.question: Which of these does using a breakpoint NOT allow you to do?

answers.text: Pause execution at a line of code.
answers.feedback: No, a breakpoint DOES allow you to pause execution at a line of code

answers.text: Output information to the console area.
answers.feedback: No, a breakpoint DOES allow you to Output information to the console area.

answers.text: Tell you exactly why your code isn't working and how to fix the problem.
answers.feedback: Yes, a breakpoint will NOT tell you exactly why your code isn't working and how to fix the problem.

questions.question: What keyword do we use to cast an object into an object of a different type?

answers.feedback:
No, the keyword we use to cast an object into an object of a different type is 'as'.

For example:
